./.title: Overview
./.body:
Coding & Cocktails Session 2:
Introduction to CSS 


Overview 
During the session we’ll introduce CSS Compilers and how they can make your styling easier. We’ll start our project with normal CSS styling and transform that into a clean and organized stylesheet using Sass!

project/.title: Project
project/.body:
Project
We'll start out trying some basic CSS styling in Part 1 to get some practice and learn how to make the page look better.  From there we'll start trying out Sass - a CSS Compiler - to work through styling a sample page more efficiently.  We’ll utilize Sass variables, mixins and nesting to make our development easier!
Prep Work 

Open your command line terminal (Git Bash on Windows, iTerm2 on Macs) and type the command:  gem install sass
Output should look similar to :


Check that you’ve got everything installed by typing:  sass -v
Output should look like this:

part-1-basic-css.html.title: Part 1: Basic CSS
part-1-basic-css.html.body:
Part 1: Basic CSS
We'll start with some sample HTML and get a chance to try out changing some styles to start getting comfortable with how CSS works.
Preparation

Navigate to the CSS Practice CodePen at  http://codepen.io/CodingCocktailsKC/pen/PWjRzG

Once you are logged in to your account, press the Fork button in the top right.

Pick out a color palette that you like to use from http://colorhunt.co.

Make note of the hex color values displayed when you hover over each color in your chosen palette.


Navigate to Google Fonts at https://fonts.google.com/

Scroll through the fonts and choose one font that you like.

Click the red + in the upper right of that font's section


At the bottom of your page, a box with the text 1 Family Selected will appear.  


Click on the 1 Family Selected section

Copy the text in the grey box under the STANDARD heading


Back in CodePen, paste the copied link tag text just above the  tag.




You now have the information you'll need when styling your page, continue on to change the styling.

styling-html.html.title: Styling HTML
styling-html.html.body:
Styling HTML

In CodePen, notice we've set up some HTML for you to practice styling.  There is already page structure content in the first box with the HTML heading.

In the middle box with the CSS heading, select the body element and change the background-color to the hexadecimal color  from your selected color palette.
 
    Remember the syntax for a CSS rule looks like this:
    
 selector {
     property: value;
 }


Select the ul element and set the list-style-type to none. Notice how the bullets disappear from each of the list item elements.

Since the list items (li elements) are being used for navigation purposes here, change them to have display: inline; styling.  Notice how that makes them sit next to each other instead of on top of each other.

Select the element with the id #main-title.

Change the font-family to the font name that you selected from google fonts.

Increase the size of the text to be four times the size of the HTML (root) font-size. 

    1rem is equivalent to the HTML (root) font-size.
    

Change the color to another color hex value from your chosen color palette.

Center the header text using the text-align property.



Select the img element.

Change the height of the image to 100px.

Change the width of the image to 200px.

    Notice how this distorts the image so when you are styling an     image make sure to keep an eye to how your styling affects the     image.
    



Select the .section class and change the background-color to another color within your chosen palette.
 Notice how the div sections don't stretch to meet the edges of the page body or eachother

Select the first section with the .section-one class

Add a border that is 5 pixels wide and solid using another of the colors from your chosen palette.

Add a margin of 20px. Notice how that made your border box move and added space around the outside of your border.

Add some padding of 40px. Notice how that made the border box bigger around the text content and added space inside your border.



In the view section scroll down until the link comes into view.  

select the a (anchor) element and use the text-decoration property to remove the underline.



Documentation
Mozilla Developer Network CSS reference documentation

project/part_2_re_-styling_with_sass.htm.title: Part 2:  Getting Sassy
project/part_2_re_-styling_with_sass.htm.body:
Part 2: Styling with Sass
You've had some practice with basic CSS, now let's move on to practicing styling a page using Sass to make life a bit easier. 
If you follow our instructions your page will end up looking like the example below but feel free to add in some of your own creativity if you feel comfortable!

Documentation
To understand the different CSS properties and available values visit the Mozilla Developer Network CSS reference documentation
View the Sass documentation here if you want more detailed information about how any pieces of Sass work: bit.ly/CnCSassDoc

sass-setup.html.title: Sass Setup
sass-setup.html.body:
Setup

In your CodingAndCocktails folder in your home directory create a CSS folder

Open Atom and set up your HTML file.

Close any open tabs in Atom by hovering over them with your mouse at the top of the screen and clicking on the small x that appears.

In the File menu choose Add Project Folder...

Navigate to the CSS folder you just created in step 1 and choose Open.

You should now have a pane on the left displaying the CSS folder. Right click on the folder and choose New File.

Type index.html and press enter.

A new file should display on the left and should open in your main work area.  

Copy and paste the following HTML code into your index.html file.


 
     
     LadyDev Bar & Grill
     
     
 
 
     
         
             Home
             About
             Menu
             Contact
         
     
     
         
             
                 
                     LadyDev
                     Bar & Grill
                 
                 Making development more delicious every day!
                 Welcome to the LadyDev Bar & Grill.  We're glad you're here!
                 Sit down, relax, and enjoy good drinks, good eats, and good friends.
             
         
         
             
                 Menu
                 
                     
                         
                         Martinis
                         Made with our own homemade gin and dry vermouth.  Choose from The Classic, Lemondrop, or Chocolate.
                     
                     
                         
                         Wine
                         There are just too many to list.  Ask your server for a recommendation.
                     
                     
                         
                         Whiskey cocktails
                         Whiskey.  Some might consider it their spirit animal.  Thank goodness it's not just for men anymore.
                     
                     
                         
                         Margaritas
                         Slushy frozen delicousness, in Peach, Strawberry, or Mango.  Served with a rock-salted rim and lime.
                     
                     
                         
                         Hot & Creamy
                         Just what you need to kick off a night of coding.  We offer concoctions with coffee, Kahlua, Bailey's, and more.
                     
                     
                         
                         Beer
                         We serve the finest microbrews from around the world.  How about a Saison, IPA, or Stout?
                     
                     
                         
                         Non alcoholic
                             We have plenty of NA options available to quench your thirst, like lemonade, milk or soda.
                     
                 
             
             
                 Small plates
                 
                     Grassfed beef sliders
                     Spicy calamari
                     Coconut shrimp
                     Veggie spring rolls
                     Deviled eggs
                     Tuscan bean dip
                     Chicken lettuce wraps
                 
             
         
     
     
         © 2017 LadyDev Bar & Grill
         
             
             
             
             
         
     
 



Save the file.



Set up project structure.

Right click again on that CSS folder in the left pane and select New Folder.  

Type sass and press enter.

Right click again on that main CSS folder in the left pane and select New Folder.  

Type css and press enter.

In the project pane on the left, right click on the sass folder and select New File. 

Type styles.scss and press enter. This will be your main Sass styling file and will only contain import statements when we’re done.



Open your index.html file in Google Chrome and notice the current styling.  You can do this two ways.

Open Google Chrome. 

From the File menu choose Open File....

Navigate to find your index.html file and choose Open.



In your File Explorer (windows) or Finder (macs) navigate to your folder containing the index.html file.

Right click on the file and choose Open with.

Choose Google Chrome from the list.






The page doesn't look very good yet but we've got our initial setup for our project done, now let's get to the fun part - styling!
Documentation
To understand the different CSS properties and available values visit the Mozilla Developer Network CSS reference documentation
View the Sass documentation here if you want more detailed information about how any pieces of Sass work: bit.ly/CnCSassDoc

styling-with-sass.html.title: Variables
styling-with-sass.html.body:
Variables
Start by creating some Sass variables that will represent the colors in the color palette that you selected earlier.

In the project pane on the left, right click on the sass folder and select New File. 

Type _variables.scss and press enter. This will be the file where all of our variables that we use in our project will be located.

Create your first variable for the main color of your site. Variables start with a $ followed by the variable name.  It might look something like the following:
 $orange: #cb6f10;

Create variables for the remaining colors in your site.  It is common to name your color variables according the color name.  Things like $turquoise, $white, $dark-purple, etc.

The variables file needs to be tied in to the project so in your styles.scss file type in @import “variables”; to import the  _variables.scss file.

Save both the styles.scss and  _variables.scss files.


Documentation
To understand the different CSS properties and available values visit the Mozilla Developer Network CSS reference documentation
View the Sass documentation here if you want more detailed information about how any pieces of Sass work: bit.ly/CnCSassDoc

normalizing.html.title: Normalizing

fonts.html.title: Fonts
fonts.html.body:
Fonts
Add fonts for your page.

Back in Google Fonts (fonts.google.com), make sure you have at least two fonts selected, one to use for headers and one to use for body text.

This time we'll find the import way of embedding the fonts by clicking on the red @IMPORT header next to the STANDARD header.
 

Copy the just the import statement for your fonts, not the surrounding  tags and paste it as the first line in your styles.scss file.

In the  _variables.scss file, set up the variables for $body-font and $header-font referencing the Google Fonts font-families. Depending on what fonts you've chosen, one variable might look like: $body-font: "Work Sans", Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
 
    If you select a font that has a name that is two words you'll need to wrap the font name in quotation marks.
    
    Often you'll want to provide backup fonts for the page to fall back on in case it can't load the chosen font. A common fallback for sans-serif fonts might include Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif. For serif fonts it might include "Times New Roman", Times, serif as backups.
    

In the  _normailze.scss file, add the font-family: property to both the body selector and the h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 selector.  Set the values to the $body-font; and $header-font; respectively.

Save the  _variables.scss,  _styles.scss, and  _normalize.scss files.

Now compile the Sass into CSS. 

In the command line (Git Bash for windows, iTerm2 for macs) make sure you are in the folder containing your index.html file.

    The command cd will let you change directory (or folder).
    The command ls will list the files in your current directory.
    The command pwd will print working directory, or, show you what directory (or folder) you're currently in.
    Join us in March for more information on these commands and more as we learn about the Command Line!
    

Type: sass sass/styles.scss css/styles.css



Go to Google Chrome and refresh your page. You should notice the font styling has changed.


Documentation
To understand the different CSS properties and available values visit the Mozilla Developer Network CSS reference documentation
View the Sass documentation here if you want more detailed information about how any pieces of Sass work: bit.ly/CnCSassDoc

nav-styling.html.title: Nav Styling

body-styling.html.title: Body Styling
body-styling.html.body:
Body Styling

In the project pane on the left, right click on the sass folder and select New File. 

Type _main.scss and press enter. This will be the partial file where the styling for the main body portion of our page will be located.

Don't forget to import main into your styles.scss file and save the file.

Start with styling the main “hero” image and text with the large page heading, a smaller “tagline” and some about text.

Select the .hero class.

Give it a height: and a width:.  A 600px; height should work well. It should cover 100%; of the width of the page.

Instead of having an  HTML element here to display the image, we'll be using a background image on our div.  

Take a look at the background property documentation on MDN.  It is a pretty powerful property with the ability to set values for multiple background properties in one.  

Set the background: property to url("../images/hero.jpg") no-repeat center top;.  

        This is telling the background property that we are using a link to find our image (url = **u**niform **r**esource **l**ocator).  Go up one directory/folder from where we are (`../`), look in the images folder (`images/`) and use the `hero.jpg` file as the background image.
        
        Also we don't want to repeat the image, we just want a single image displayed (`no-repeat`).
        
        The image should be `center`ed horizontally and align the `top` of the image with the top of the background layer.
        

Finally, make sure the background-size: is set to cover; to make the image cover the width and height of the container.



Select the .hero-text class and give it a width: of 50%; and add a padding-top.  See if you can find a good value for the top padding so it doesn't sit right at the top of the page and looks nice.

Also make sure your text is centered.  Hint: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/text-align.

Set the color: and font-size: to appropriate values for the h1, h2 and p elements.

You'll also want to add some extra margin on the bottom of the h2 element to separate it from the p text.



Below the "hero" set up two columns for your main page content and a sidebar.  We'll use the flexbox model here to help us out.
 For more information on using flexible boxes see https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Flexible_Box_Layout/Using_CSS_flexible_boxes.

Select the .flexbox class.

Add the display: property with the flex; value to set up our layout.

We're setting up just a single row with this so set the flex-flow: property to row;.

Nested inside the flexbox selector, add a selector for the .col-1 class.

To set the size of .col-1 set the flex: property to 3 1 75%;.  This will tell the first column how much space to take up inside the .flexbox flex container.

After the } for the .col-1 rules, add a selector for .col-2.  Set the flex: property to 1 3 25%; 

In the .col-2 styles you'll also want to change the background-color: and font-size:.



Style the menu item list.

Select the drinks class.

Remove the bullets from the list. (Remember how you did this in the nav styling?)

Nested in the drinks selector, select the h2 element and set a font-size and margin of 3em and 5px respectively.

Nested in the drinks selector but after the closing } of the h2 selector, select the item class.  The ellipses ... indicate code not written out in the example, they should not be a part of your code.
.drinks {
     ...

     h2 {
         ...
     }

     .item {
     }
}


Add a margin-bottom: of 60px;

Add a top 1 pixel dotted border that is one of the colors from your color palette

Set the top padding to 10px;

Set the display: property to block;

Nested in the drinks selector but after the closing } of the item class selector, select the head class.

Enlarge the head font size to twice that of the current font size.

    1em is equal to the current font-size of the element in question
    

Nested in the drinks selector but after the closing } of the head class selector, select the p (paragraph) element.

Enlarge the paragraph font size to 1.3 times the current font size.

Nested in the drinks selector but after the closing } of the p element selector, select the img (image) element.

float: the image left;.

Add a margin, height and width for your image.  Suggested values are:
margin: 0 20px;
height: 120px;
width: 120px;


Save your file.

In the command line, type sass --watch sass/styles.scss:css/styles.css so sass will watch for changes to your scss file and automatically compile them.  

Use a border-radius: to make the image circular.  Try different values to see what they look like.  Save the file and refresh in Google Chrome to view changes.  

    Since sass is set to watch for changes we are taking out the manual step to compile the Sass into CSS.
    

Nested in the drinks selector but after the closing } of the img element selector, select the a (anchor) element. 

Remove the text decoration and set the text color. Hint: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/text-decoration

Check out your page content in Google Chrome.  Things should be looking like they're coming together now!



Style the sidebar "Small Plates" content on the right side.

Below the closing } for the drinks class selector, select the sidebar class.

See if you can style the h2 and ul elements inside the sidebar class to look similar to the example image that you can view here: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/KansasCityWomeninTechnology/CSSCompilerPractice/master/ladyDevBarAndGrill.png 



Save the  _main.scss file and reload the page in Google Chrome.  Your page should be looking a lot more stylish than when we started! Keep up the hard work!


Documentation
To understand the different CSS properties and available values visit the Mozilla Developer Network CSS reference documentation
View the Sass documentation here if you want more detailed information about how any pieces of Sass work: bit.ly/CnCSassDoc

footer-styling.html.title: Footer Styling
footer-styling.html.body:
Footer Styling
Style a footer with copyright information and social media links.

In the project pane on the left, right click on the sass folder and select New File. 

Type _footer.scss and press enter. This will be the partial file where the styling for the main body portion of our page will be located.

Don't forget to import footer into your styles.scss file.

See if you can set some styles for the footer on your own.  The example image can be found here: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/KansasCityWomeninTechnology/CSSCompilerPractice/master/ladyDevBarAndGrill.png
 You might be able to look at the  _nav.scss file for some styling ideas. Also be sure to look at the Mozilla Developer Network (MDN) documentation linked at the bottom of the page to read about the CSS properties you want to use. If you get stuck call a mentor over to talk it through!
 
    Notice in the MDN documentation that you can open the examples and play with them in CodePen.  JSFiddle is another similar tool but since we used CodePen earlier you should already have an account there.
    
 

Save your styles.scss and  _footer.scss files and compile the Sass into CSS. 

In the command line (Git Bash for windows, iTerm2 for macs) make sure you are in the folder containing your index.html file.

Type: sass sass/styles.scss css/styles.css



Go to Google Chrome and refresh your page. You should have a more visually appealing footer now.  If it doesn't look quite like the sample image try setting some more styles and see if you can get it closer.  Don't forget to save, compile and refresh your page in Google Chrome to see your changes!


Documentation
To understand the different CSS properties and available values visit the Mozilla Developer Network CSS reference documentation
View the Sass documentation here if you want more detailed information about how any pieces of Sass work: bit.ly/CnCSassDoc

mixins.html.title: Mixins

homework.html.title: Homework
homework.html.body:
Homework 
The more you practice, the more comfortable you’ll feel!  Take a look at the following tutorials:

Play a game to understand CSS Selectors better: http://flukeout.github.io/

To understand flexbox layouts better try: http://flexboxfroggy.com/

Practice more CSS styling on Codecademy: https://www.codecademy.com/courses/css-coding-with-style

Walk through this tutorial by 1stWebDesigner.com to get more Sass practice: bit.ly/SassTut   

    If the pictures don’t display appropriately in the tutorial you can click on where they should be showing to display them)
    

For more practice and a focus only on the Sass without worrying about your HTML try this tutorial from Scotch.io: bit.ly/SassTut3

css_cheat_sheet.html.title: CSS Cheat Sheet
css_cheat_sheet.html.body:
CSS Cheat Sheet 
This cheat sheet shares some commonly used CSS properties. If you want to know how to do something googling it is usually very helpful often taking you to stack overflow or w3schools.  Try searching google for CSS margin to get a better understanding of the margin property.  Another place to look is the documentation on the mozilla developer network pages here: bit.ly/MDNDOC 



Property
Description
Value
Example




margin
Adds spacing around an element outside the border (refer to the box model diagram to the left)
Any pixel number value
p { margin: 10px; } p { margin: 0 auto; }


padding
Add spacing between the element content and the element border (refer to the box model diagram above)
Any pixel number value
p { padding: 10px 0 15px 20px }


border
Specifies the border styling
Width: any pixel number value
p { border: 2px solid blue; }


color
Sets the font color
Hex color values or color names
p { color: #ffffff; }


text-align
Aligns text according to value
left
p { text-align: center; }


text-decoration
Add decoration to text
none
a { text-decoration: none; }


font-family
Set the font family (or typeface) of the text
Any font name
p { font-family: Neuton, "Times New Roman", Times, serif; }


font-size
Set the size of the text
Numeric value in px, em or rem
h1 { font-size: 4em; }


font-style
Sets the text style
Normal
h4{ font-style: italic; }


font-weight
Set the weight of the text
normal
h3 { font-weight: bold }


background-color
Sets the color of the selected elements background
Any hex color value or color name
body { background-color: #ffffff; }


background-image
Set the background of the element to the image supplied
Image url
.hero { background-image: url(‘images/image.png’); }


background-repeat
Specifies whether or not a background image should be repeated
repeat
body { background-repeat: no-repeat; }


background-position
Sets the starting position of a background image
center center
.hero { background-position: right center; }


list-style-type
Determines the bullet style on the list
circle
ul { list-style-type: none; }


float
Specifies whether an element should float.
Right
img { float: left; }


clear
Does not allow floating to the specified side of an element
Right
.footer { clear: both; }

answer-key.html.title: Answer Key
answer-key.html.body:
Answer Key
Compare your .scss files with our answer key here: 
https://github.com/KansasCityWomeninTechnology/CSSCompilerPractice/tree/sass-key/sass. 
Click on each file name to open it and view the file's contents.
It may not be exact depending on what creative liberties you've taken but will give you an idea on what your Sass may look like.
